p: Inexpensive modified lignocellulosic materials hold great promise for the development of biopolymer-based catalysts [1]. Biomass-derived biopolymers play an important role in the mitigation of fossil fuel depletion and global warming caused by the use of synthetic polymers [2, 3]. As a representative sustainable biopolymer, cellulose features high natural abundance, belonging to the green support group [3, 4], and can be isolated from rice straw (among other sources), which is an abundant, cheap, and green material that is generated in large quantities as a byproduct of rice production [5, 6] and has a high cellulose content [7, 8].
